document.title: Washington, DC K-12 Social Studies Standards Revised Standards

73143A089AC84FC28AD7F430329038B6.description:
Propose and advocate for a specific method of action that can be taken by the federal government to best respond to a
current situation in which a country is at risk for genocide or mass atrocity.

3F5F881707764F7DB720FCD8F81C5A53.description:
Evaluate the ways in which countries and international organizations recognize and respond to indications that a country is
at risk for genocide or mass atrocity.

B84A7A324F844BA5913B2E613F8ED3E2.description:
Analyze the common risk factors and warning signs that indicate a country is at risk for genocide or mass atrocity and identify
how they have been present during the Holocaust and at least one other genocide.

F9B02464420B4EAEB6FDD94F77FFD0E4.description:
Compare the effectiveness of methods used by the United States government to enact foreign policy, including sanctions,
aid, diplomacy, military force, coalition building, and deterrence.

1F8C409C5CAA4B7AB63E3978F4B26CAA.description: Analyze the ways in which at least three different countries impact policy beyond their borders.

1AAEB1A938DD47C58DF0E5ACAF302782.description:
In this driving concept, students will evaluate the efficacy of different tools of foreign policy that different countries and the
United States use to impact global change. Students will evaluate the factors that lead to mass atrocity such as global genocide.
Students should study different actions global citizens can take to address foreign crises and evaluate each action for its
effectiveness. These standards are best taught using a case study approach in which students apply their understanding to a
specific global event and take action.

C9E47DE89753450DBA0DD823DFA4E0AF.description: Driving Concept 7: Global Opportunities for Action

DB9E651CFBDC461990E79DAB6DDCFF37.description:
Identify a local, national or international issue, assess options for taking action, and construct an action proposal designed
to make change.

2D15E92D99C8413BABA87AAD5285FD74.description: Evaluate the role and efficacy of civil disobedience, mass protest and strikes in creating change.

53836AE0B231460D819DA93A43CFE01E.description:
Analyze an individual or a group involved in a historic or current protest movement to evaluate their efforts to achieve
reform or improve society.

176ACA853B5843F6956521F94094469C.description: Evaluate the effectiveness of non-governmental organizations in Washington, DC at participating in and creating change.

C5D29D0A6CB14BF28D9C3D5B6A8CEC3B.description:
Analyze the significance of Washington, DC as a historic and current location for national protests, rallies or other
demonstrations.

9FF786D1D82D473D92953C96D59084EB.description: Evaluate lasting and short-term impacts of protests to economic, social and environmental policy.

6B6294B9F2D44859A684455F4CB7894D.description: Analyze the ways in which media and technology have been used as tools for resistance and protest.

D66147829B8B4B85B231AB932AE16981.description:
Compare the tactics, strategies, leaders, major events and enduring impacts of at least two different social movements
within the US.

523C64E7E34F4618AC9C2C34A50773B3.description:
Analyze how the First Amendment of the US Constitution has been interpreted to limit or provide opportunities for citizen
action to protest, resist and influence government policy.

98DD1C86C1AC4C859BF09F78F2175606.description:
Analyze global examples of citizen action to enact change through protests and resistance to government action, and
evaluate their success in achieving their stated purpose and the long-term effects of the action.

FEBF17724EF943A6BDE5C316CFC9C0E8.description:
In this driving concept, students will understand how effective protest and resistance can lead to economic, political, and social
change. Students will analyze the challenges of engaging civic action at the local, national and global levels and evaluate the
effects of civic action on public policy in the United States and other countries. Students should study the actions of groups who
protest and resist oppressive government actions, laws, or policies. These standards are best taught using a case study approach
in which students apply their understanding to a specific policy issue

2FD32255F9D54517B2DD14CF0382F868.description:
Identify a local, national or international issue connected to access to power and representation, conduct relevant research,
identify and assess policy options, and construct a public policy proposal designed to improve the situation.

4F4A972CB3C94BA69A58320D8501D88F.description: Analyze the impact of urban geography and zoning on access to power and opportunity in Washington, DC.

E4D38D3CEB2A4F36954C04C10C250F23.description: Identify and analyze opportunities to access political power in Washington, DC to initiate and support change.

E9657C8F41F94939B5780F03B90663C8.description:
Evaluate the change in access to local and national power in Washington, DC over time and the impact of these changes on
the government of Washington, DC.

70FCEE6DB6EF4C16A4330F346273C967.description:
8 Analyze the way in which national or local policy has shaped access to resources and opportunity or increased exposure to
harmful environmental effects and how people have sought to address this.

9339C92FEC274559816B4C35BB348203.description:
Compare 21st-century voter suppression to voter suppression in previous centuries, and analyze the historic, racialized, and
economic effects of voter suppression on various groups.

212A511E1F934752BC0D6B44C78BB1EF.description: Compare the ability of different individuals and public and private interest groups to influence public policy

8CFE7A94118C4A0DADDAB6145DD63DDA.description:
Evaluate the impact of the federal system and the structure of the federal government on the abilities of individuals in
different states, territories and Indigenous Nations to influence national policy.

098EF6B3BF804DCB9983115E85E86341.description:
Analyze how international alliances and agreements (e.g., the United Nations, North Atlantic Treaty Organization, North
American Free Trade Agreement, International Monetary Fund, treaties with Indigenous Nations,) expand and limit people’s
access to power around the world.

AF910C63AAD2416D986F65F935436CB6.description:
Through this driving concept, students will think critically about how power and the access to power have shaped public policy
and societal experiences from a global, national and local perspective. Students will analyze the impact of race, gender, religion,
ethnicity and socio-economic status on access to power locally and globally. Students will evaluate the relationship between the
people and government, identifying, acknowledging, and solving real-world issues. Throughout this driving concept, students
should evaluate a specific public policy case, such as environmental policy, through the lens of power and create a proposal for
taking action.

9C3749D7243345E2BB727DCDCA96AA52.description: Driving Concept 5: Power and Access to Power in Society

AE08F86635314EDEADE12E868C59185F.description:
Identify a local, national or international issue connected to human rights, conduct relevant research, identify and assess
policy options to address the issue, and construct a public policy proposal designed to improve the situation.

C74B917C998242E5A57593062AB9AB34.description:
Evaluate the status of Washington, DC in the federal government, the impact on the rights of the citizens and residents of the
District and the movement for DC statehood.

23F26F6662C142C2AC11B13B7BCE2836.description:
Evaluate contemporary debates about the proper application of the rights reserved through the Bill of Rights, and develop a
proposal for personal or collective action to address the issue.

784802C88D88453880C1A8DDC776E2DB.description: Evaluate contemporary debates about the proper enforcement of the 13th, 14th and 15th Amendments

4BC09F8B9E224AFD940BA988D6AA317F.description:
Analyze a current economic issue that curtails or infringes on the rights of individuals and groups and offer alternative
approaches to address the needs of different individuals, groups and society.

99855C712E634A1E842352215C6D46DF.description:
Evaluate the ways different activist groups have used the court system to expand or limit the rights of different individuals
and groups.

39134438A1AE43C3BF08FDA0E9341AFE.description: Analyze at least 3 historic Supreme Court cases that establish, extend or limit the rights of individuals.

D0F707A03D2743A99C3AB28EB483307B.description:
Identify the rights of individuals and groups codified in the US Constitution, and evaluate the extent to which those rights
have been realized.

8724CBD33118462A9296AB0C721BA8B4.description: Analyze the history of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the rights enumerated in the document.

3A369BAD64AD494583C13E551831C51C.description:
Analyze the rights of citizens in at least three countries around the world and how the government upholds or violates these
rights, and evaluate the extent to which the public has the ability to influence the decision-making of different governments
globally.

A1940F41DFE6496185EA5EB4475841AC.description:
Through this driving concept, students will investigate the ways in which governments attempt to balance individual rights with
public safety and order. Students should compare the different rights and protections of citizens around the world with the
rights and protections provided by the United States government. Students should analyze the reasons for the evolution of rights
over time, including the broadening definition of “citizen,” and evaluate the reasons different groups have been excluded from
constitutional protections over time. Students should also evaluate the rights of District residents. Throughout this driving
concept, students should evaluate a specific public policy case through the lens of rights and create a proposal for taking action.

4FAB1A5600444E34BDF502D0CE0C7371.description: Driving Concept 4: Rights of the People

0459171A9C5946C4B841C73968EE9203.description: Develop a plan to use technology and online platforms for civic engagement and to drive social change.

A558E187AB2E4CE8A148BC1A00135FB9.description:
Critically evaluate price, product claims, and quality of information from a variety of sources to make informed consumer
decisions.

8177913B78DB499E8E3D5870B317B031.description:
Analyze the role of social media in shaping political ideology, framing policy debates, and accurately informing the public
about major policy issues within the United States.

0A147B47566A4708A7938666012C5663.description: Analyze historical examples of using art or mass media to successfully influence public policy outcomes.

17FE17A62A494606B4BFA7000BCE7FC9.description:
Evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of traditional news media organizations (newspapers, magazines, and television) in
creating an informed public, including an analysis of the use of fact checkers, editors, framing and focus.

25895116D58D492584C5B5DE1079AD88.description: Compare multiple accounts from different news or media sources about an issue of concern

65E655BA5DD64A9ABEBFE6F044518375.description:
Analyze the point of view and evaluate the claims of an editorial, editorial cartoon or op-ed commentary on a public policy
issue at the local, state or national level.

E5D721D03E244AE0B5D5E6CA21F04347.description: Identify resources to reference (e.g., fact checking and news organizations) while evaluating online sources and claims.

E52E72C8A15C41229662B539914B301F.description:
Evaluate the accuracy of a range of claims made by digital sources through lateral reading when information about the
source is unavailable.

3FFEC1CD01E64D2DA288CD2EF3D560AC.description:
Evaluate the credibility of a range of digital sources using civic online reasoning strategies including lateral reading and click
restraint.

240A65ACDB524125AF3F17A7D45CBF69.description:
Compare the ways in which individuals in at least three different countries around the world receive information, including
an analysis of the relationship between different governments and media

0D4AF3392D8340D39EE8F2ACB247AE73.description:
This driving concept will engage students in a critical analysis of the role of media and social media in shaping the understanding
and narrative of a policy question. Students will understand how to use media to investigate a contemporary issue and how to
investigate the reliability of a website or organization. Students will understand how to evaluate coverage, framing and missing
viewpoints in traditional news sources. This driving concept is best explored through explicit instruction in digital literacy
strategies and practice with curated materials.

1780A382ED3049E69D20D84E56F3376D.description: Driving Concept 3: Media, Society, Government, and Digital Literacy

AFE780D8FA79466CB40F0A8ED27D5B9A.description:
Propose and advocate for specific changes to the structure and function of federal or local government to best meet the
needs of the people, and/or propose a specific way to best create change within the current system.

01B268CC963C495B9695FB115EAC5A1D.description:
Evaluate the effectiveness of the structure and functions of the Washington, DC government in enacting policies that are
reflective of community concerns.

0986D3123969497B9D418D1E8783F1D4.description:
Evaluate the extent to which the interests of Washington, DC residents are represented in the federal government and
evaluate the impact of the relationship between the District and the federal government on local policy.

3A6C79F40D854B9189DA348C48E1952D.description:
Explain the structure and powers of the Washington, DC government, including the features of the Executive, Legislative
and Judicial branches.

7BA80A2EFA8E4126BA1AA33D946440CA.description: Assess the responsiveness of elected federal officials in enacting policies reflective of national public concerns and interests.

E19249B87C1E451CAAFCDEE58592FED5.description:
Evaluate the efficacy of different government policies in helping individuals increase their personal savings and economic
resilience.

D9E4C8613A4C4ED796150D622747F343.description:
Identify elected leaders in the legislative and executive branches of the federal and local governments and identify multiple
ways for citizens to contact government officials to advocate for legislation or public policy.

424D878FA6DE4BEEA0FCCEF4C5F9B81D.description: Analyze a current Supreme Court ruling to understand the role of the court system in the United States.

9CDDDBA10B1A45F79096966882A7E759.description: Analyze a historic or current executive action to evaluate the power and limitations of presidential executive orders.

2A103737CF944E5899DA4EB3BF0578AF.description:
Analyze a historic or current piece of legislation or law such as the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) to evaluate the role
of citizens, interest groups, and corporations, as well as elected leaders, in the legislative process.

9C9B82416B7F471BBDDDADD8D9065C16.description:
Analyze how a historic or current piece of legislation or law such as the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) impacts
citizens.

C102952DD8614EA697FCCE9ED6E3B0F1.description: Explain how a bill becomes a law in the federal government and evaluate the efficacy of the current system.

78313F2D32F84B729C3C3BE879697918.description: Analyze the structures and functions of the three branches of the US federal government.

3320F11F5C3A4E93AEA076265996FE0B.description: Evaluate and compare the structures of government across three different countries or Indigenous Nations.

2DD9349FCBBE4FD38AF9E760CE735A39.description:
This driving concept uses inquiry to engage students in a critical analysis of ways different governments around the world and
within the US function. Students should compare the different ways in which governments around the world create and enforce
laws to the ways in which the United States creates and enforces laws. Students should also evaluate the ways that the local
government provides goods and services to residents of the District. Throughout this driving concept, students should evaluate a
specific public policy case and create a proposal advocating for the benefits of the current system, or propose a change that
would improve the ways in which the federal or local government meets the needs of residents.

E9793A0BDB2F45578C8639D1BC8B19E6.description: Driving Concept 2: How does the Government Function?

367CDCC774884FB3B8C9668B260960FD.description: Construct a claim about the role of the government in the lives of citizens and residents of the United States.

6B13FA20C64842B39C51C63AC71EC524.description:
Analyze the role of the Washington, DC government over time including its power to enact policy to address economic, social
and political problems.

A7A02548BB264FC8A0D0EB2B85008AF5.description:
Analyze explicit liberties guaranteed by the US Constitution and explain how these liberties have been used to influence the
role and purpose of government.

D37DB0ED2F44489E9AD9FC6EFBD3987D.description: Evaluate how the role of the US federal government has expanded and contracted historically.

B062A8FE4C10428E9394333B447E30CA.description:
Analyze the historical and philosophical influences on the creation of the American government system, including the role of
race, gender, religion, and socioeconomic status.

2BEA4B5D17F24356B79FBAD00E8AA380.description:
Evaluate major tensions within United States’ constitutional democracy, including majority rule and individual rights, liberty
and security, civil disobedience and the rule of law, local versus federal control, and the size and scope of the federal government.

86E45B205F574F9D918F92558BFC2CE4.description:
Use excerpts from documents that shape constitutional democracy in the United States, such as the Declaration of
Independence, the Preamble to the Constitution, and the Federalist Papers, to analyze principles about the role of the
government.

93255F3DECE8441D96CC421EF3DC38C0.description:
Evaluate and compare competing ideas for the purpose of government and the role of the people across three different
countries or Indigenous Nations.

D5D9B2C7354D4D3D90CA9389A4A8527B.description:
This driving concept helps students understand the different global and historical philosophies that inform the role of
government in society. Students should compare the expectations citizens around the world have regarding the role of
government to the ways in which residents of the United States view the role of government. Students should also evaluate the
role of local government in providing goods or services to residents of the District. Throughout this driving concept, students
should evaluate a specific public policy case, and create a proposal about the appropriate level of government intervention in the
policy case they are studying.

E35DF215E3134317BFBD60B5CA881084.description: Driving Concept 1: What is the Role of Government in Society?
